awd_titl_txt: Sampled Data Driven Attack Detection and Adaptation for Security in Control Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to contribute to cyber-attack resilient control methods and architectures, which are critically important to safe operation of power grid, medical, manufacturing, traffic and many other control systems.  Malicious attacks on modern time cyber infrastructure have been a daily phenomenon and a constant threat for the nation's security and well-being. There have been numerous cyber-attacks that infiltrated critical industrial control systems, vehicle control units, GPS systems used for navigation and control, air-vehicle autopilots, SCADA systems in the power grid, etc.  In all of these cyber-attacks the aim is to deceive the control and monitoring mechanism and potentially lead the system to instability and malfunction, thus causing physical damages that could be of catastrophic nature.  As control systems are becoming sophisticated and frequently include components from cyberspace, their security is generating greater challenges.  The project focuses on theoretical advancements in resilient control methods as well as experimental safety demonstrations with UAV systems.  It also promotes the engagement of undergraduate students with the topic of safe control system analysis and design.
    
This project aims to address cyber-security for control systems from a control theory perspective, in order to develop controller analysis and synthesis methods applicable for secure software and hardware architectures in order to accurately assess and reduce the risks of such attacks.  In practice controllers are implemented digitally and physical plants evolve in a continuous-time domain. The sampled-data control implementation generates additional vulnerability to stealthy attacks, which, if ignored, can result in a catastrophic event. Security associated with the attacks of interest cannot be dealt with solely by robust controller design nor by standard security software. Instead this project takes the approach of co-designing the control algorithm along with the secure software/hardware platform on which the controller operates, all in a sampled-data framework.  The proposed schemes and theoretical results will be verified experimentally using unmanned aerial vehicles.

por.por_cntn:
Malicious attacks on modern time cyber infrastructure have been a daily phenomenon and a constant threat for the nation's security and well-being. There have been numerous cyber-attacks that infiltrated critical industrial control systems, vehicle control units, GPS systems used for navigation and control, air-vehicle autopilots, SCADA systems in the power grid, etc. In all of these cyber-attacks the aim is to deceive the control and monitoring mechanism and potentially lead the system to instability and malfunction, thus causing physical damages that could be of catastrophic nature. As control systems are becoming sophisticated and frequently include components from cyberspace, their security is generating greater challenges. This project aims to contribute to cyber-attack resilient control methods and architectures, which are critically important to safe operation of power grid, medical, manufacturing, traffic and many other control systems.  

 

The major outcomes and findings of the project include:  

 Analysis and Synthesis of Sampled-Data Control Systems

Based on our developed a sampled-data (SD) controller for uncertain control systems, it is shown that the hybrid closed-loop system can recover the performance of a continuous-time reference system as the sampling time of the SD controller tends to zero.

On the Computation of Worst Attacks: a LP Framework

Through employing an L-infinity framework, we show how tractable Linear Programming methods can be used to obtain the design the worst possible attack. Moreover, we provide a controller synthesis iterative method to minimize the impact of the worst-case attack and we test its efficacy in a power system component.

Attack-resilient Estimation for Stochastic Systems

By means of projections, we design an attack-resilient estimation algorithm given inequality constraints on the states and the attacks. It has been shown that the projection reduces the estimation error, as well as the error covariance. It has been further shown that the estimation error is practically exponentially stable.

Novel Stealthy Attack and Defense Strategies for Networked Control Systems

We propose realistic ZDA variations where the attacker is aware of this topology-switching strategy, and hence can avoid detection. Particularly, we characterize conditions for detectability of the proposed ZDA variations, in terms of the network topologies to be maintained, the set of agents to be monitored, and the measurements of the monitored agents that should be extracted, while simultaneously preserving the privacy of the states of the non-monitored agents. 

SL1-Simplex Software Architecture

We propose a novel extension of the Simplex architecture with model switching and model learning: SL1-Simplex. This architecture tolerates detected cyber attack and concurrent software and physical failures and enhances CPS resilient autonomy without accurate system models at hand in unforeseen operating environments.

 

To achieve the goals of the project, the group lead by PI Petros Voulgaris and Co-PI  Naira Hovakimyan has developed control and estimation algorithms and fault tolerant software architecture to secure systems, through (1) extending the L1 adaptive control theory to the multi-rate sampled-data control framework, (2) designing resilient state estimation algorithms, and introducing a new security measure, (3) designing novel attack design algorithms, and (4) developing fault and attack tolerant software architecture. The group investigated an attack resilient estimation and detection algorithm against false data injection attacks and introduced a new security measure for secure control. In addition, a worst-case attack design has been studied in the LP framework and an iterative control design method has been proposed. A multi-level sampled-data control structure is also proposed for safe and secure control of autonomous systems in the presence of uncertainties, physical failures, and cyber-attacks where the stealthy zero-dynamics attacks become detectable by considering a multi-rate formulation. Meanwhile, a novel strategic topology switching is proposed to secure networked cyber-physical systems through fighting stealthy attacks.  Finally, the SL1-Simplex software architecture is proposed to tolerate and mitigate the detected attacks in cyber-physical systems. 

 


Last Modified: 11/12/2021
Modified by: Petros Voulgaris
